description: From Medieval Latin incarcerātus, past participle of incarcerō (“to imprison”), from Latin in- (“in”) + carcer (“a prison”), meaning "put behind lines (bars)" – Latin root is of a lattice or grid. Related to cancel (“cross out with lines”) and chancel (“area behind a lattice”).

verbs.description: incarcerate (third-person singular simple present incarcerates, present participle incarcerating, simple past and past participle incarcerated)

entries.meaning: (chiefly US) To lock away; to imprison, especially for breaking the law.
examples: Tolokonnikova has also been an effective public speaker even while incarcerated, but she has spoken out on politics and freedom in general rather than prisoners’ rights.

entries.meaning: To confine; to shut up or enclose; to hem in.
